content: The list of independent counsels appointed by the special Division of the Court for Appointing Independent Counsels includes names, areas of investigation, results, and cost information. This information is derived from audits by the Government Accountability Office or Senate Committee on Governmental Affairs reports. The Government Accountability Office and Senate Committee on Governmental Affairs report on independent counsel investigations prior to 1985. The total costs of investigations were derived from six-month GAO audit reports on expenditures. The list includes appointed independent counsels and special prosecutors, some of whom are kept confidential. Total costs of 20 investigations have been incurred. The total costs of 20 independent counsel or special prosecutor investigations have amounted to approximately $228,712,589. The statutory provisions for the appointment of independent counsels expired in 1999, and no new independent counsels can be appointed. The statutory provisions for independent counsels expired in 1999, preventing new appointments. The Attorney General can now hire temporary personnel for investigations. Special counsel investigations have incurred significant costs, such as $6,073,000 for the Whitewater investigation and $15,536,793 for the Waco incident probe. The GAO released figures on the costs of various investigations, including $6,073,000 for the Whitewater investigation by Robert Fiske and $15,536,793 for the Waco incident probe by John Danforth. Patrick Fitzgerald was designated as Special Counsel to investigate the CIA leak, with expenses totaling $902,118 as of September 31, 2005. The Independent Counsel investigations resulted in no indictments in 12 out of 20 cases. In the 8 cases where indictments were returned, 3 did not involve the principal Government official initially targeted. In 5 cases where officials were indicted, 3 were acquitted or had their convictions overturned. Of the 20 independent counsel investigations initiated, only two federal officials who were the named subjects were convicted or pleaded guilty to charges brought against them. In one case, a presidential aide was convicted of perjury, while in another case, a Secretary pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor charge and was eventually pardoned by the President. Seymour investigation of presidential aide Michael Deaver resulted in a conviction for perjury and a suspended sentence. Independent Counsel Barrett investigated Secretary Cisneros, who pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor charge, was fined, and later pardoned by the President. Special prosecutors appointed under federal law have investigated various allegations, including cocaine use by officials like Hamilton Jordan and Tim Kraft, with mixed outcomes. Jacob's investigation involved allegations against President Reagan's Secretary of Labor Raymond J. Donovan, but found insufficient evidence for prosecution. The investigation cost $318,000 and no indictments were sought. Additional investigation in 1985 found no false testimony before a grand jury. The total cost of the second investigation was $7,200. The supplemental investigative reports in 1982 and 1985 cost $318,000 and $7,200 respectively. Independent counsel Jacob A. Stein found no basis for criminal charges against Edwin Meese. Alexia Morrison investigated false testimony allegations against Theodore B. Olson but found insufficient evidence. Alexia Morrison was appointed as independent counsel to investigate allegations against Theodore B. Olson for giving false testimony to Congress. The investigation found insufficient credible evidence of false statements or obstruction of justice. The final report was released on March 14, 1989, with a total cost of $2,141,000. Whitney North Seymour Jr. was also appointed to investigate charges against Michael K. Deaver for violating post-employment conflict of interest laws. Deaver was convicted of perjury on December 16, 1987, sentenced to three years probation, and fined $100,000. Michael K. Deaver, a former Reagan aide, was convicted of perjury on December 16, 1987, for violating post-employment conflict of interest laws. He was sentenced to three years probation and fined $100,000. The independent counsel's final report on the investigation cost $1,552,000. Lawrence E. Walsh was appointed to investigate the Iran-Contra matter involving Oliver North and other officials. Several individuals pleaded guilty to offenses related to the case. Several individuals pleaded guilty to various offenses related to the Iran-Contra matter, including Elliott Abrams, Carl R. "Spitz" Channell, Alan D. Fiers, Albert Hakim, Robert C. McFarlane, Richard R. Miller, and Air Force Major General Richard V. Secord. Several individuals involved in the Iran-Contra matter were convicted or indicted, including Duane Clarridge, Joseph F. Fernandez, and Casper Weinberger. President George Bush pardoned individuals involved in the Iran-Contra matter, including Casper Weinberger and Duane Clarridge, who were indicted or found guilty. The Independent Counsel's final report on the Iran-Contra matter was filed in August 1993, with the investigation costing $47,873,400. James C. McKay was appointed to investigate allegations related to Franklyn C. Nofziger and potential conflicts of interest, including influence peddling and lobbying activities for Wedtech Corporation. McKay also looked into Attorney General Edwin Meese's conduct regarding Wedtech Corporation, financial holdings, conflicts of interest, and the Aqaba Pipeline project. The Independent Counsel concluded in a July 1988 report on criminal conflicts of interest. The final report was filed on July 18, 1988, with a total investigation cost of $2,796,000. James R. Harper replaced Carl S. Rauh in August 1987, with an investigation cost of $50,000. The investigation cost $3,089,082 according to the Government Accountability Office. Julie F. Thomas succeeded Robert W. Ray as Independent Counsel in March 2002, following Kenneth W. Starr. Starr had been appointed in 1994 to investigate Whitewater allegations involving President Clinton and the First Lady. The investigation's cost was $3,089,082 according to the Government Accountability Office. The jurisdiction of Independent Counsel Starr was expanded multiple times to investigate various matters involving the White House, including the firing of staff from the travel office and the misuse of FBI files. The investigation also looked into possible false statements made by White House Counsel Nussbaum and allegations of subornation of perjury, obstruction of justice, or intimidation of witnesses by Monica Lewinsky. Results included guilty pleas from several individuals. The independent counsel investigated allegations of subornation of perjury, obstruction of justice, and intimidation of witnesses by Monica Lewinsky and others in the civil case Jones v. Clinton. Hubbell on June 30, 1999, Independent Counsel Starr confirmed that the "Whitewater aspect" of the Clintons' investigation was concluded, with no indictments for the President or First Lady. Independent Counsel Ray's statement on September 20, 2000, further clarified that there was insufficient evidence to prove their involvement in any criminal conduct related to Madison Guarantee, CMS, or Whitewater Development. Additionally, Independent Counsel Ray's reports to the Special Division of the Court on March 16, 2000, found no criminal conduct by Anthony Marceca, senior White House officials, or First Lady Hillary Rodham Clinton in obtaining derogatory information about former White House staff. On March 16, 2000, Independent Counsel Ray released reports regarding FBI file information and testimony before Congress, finding no criminal conduct by Anthony Marceca, senior White House officials, or First Lady Hillary Rodham Clinton. On June 22, 2000, no criminal indictments were sought for White House aide David Watkins or the First Lady regarding the White House travel office. The report released on October 18, 2000, stated that there was insufficient evidence to establish criminal conduct beyond a reasonable doubt.
